was leading five hundred upÄsakas to where ÅšÄriputra was, made obeisance, and then sat back.

They then went to where the Buddha was, touched their heads to the ground, joined palms, circumambulated the Buddha three times, and then sat back.
The Buddha asked Heda AnapÄ:
What merits and virtues do you have, that you are able to transform five hundred disciples to follow you?
Heda AnapÄ then knelt for a long time with palms joined and said:
I always respectfully practice the four things spoken by the Buddha.
What are the four?
First, giving to others;
second, speaking good words;
third, looking after fellow students and providing for their needs;
fourth, sharing wealth with fellow students without counting the cost.
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!ğŸ”½The Buddhas of the past had nothing to surpass these four things;
The Buddhas of the future will also have nothing to surpass these four things;
The Buddhas of the present also have nothing to surpass these four things.
After the Buddha finished speaking the sutra for He-tou-sha-mo-ni, everyone greatly rejoiced and withdrew.

He-tou-sha-mo-ni returned home, called the people, guests, and servants to sit in front of him, spoke the sutra for them to open their understanding, and spoke of the good and evil paths of birth and death;
He then went upstairs and called the treasurers and courtesans to sit in front of him, spoke the precepts for them, and they all greatly rejoiced;

He then went to the back hall and spoke the precepts for the noble ladies and women. After finishing, he returned to the main hall, sat upright in concentration on the fasting bed, and immediately attained equanimity.

In the first heaven, the Four Heavenly Kings invited all the gods to assemble and sit together, praising the merits of He Dian Anan. The most honored king among the Four Heavenly Kings descended to He Dian Anan's abode and personally praised He Dian Anan's merits.
At that time, He Dian Anan attained equanimity and did not reply to the Heavenly King.
There was a bhiká¹£u by the Buddha's side who went to He Dian Anan's abode. He Dian Anan rose to welcome the bhiká¹£u and sat in front of him. The bhiká¹£u said:
The Buddha always praises your merits while sitting.
He Dian Anan asked the bhiká¹£u:
When the Buddha praises me, are there laypeople around?
The bhiká¹£u said:
There are no laypeople.
Even if there were laypeople, what suspicion is there?
He Dian Anan said:
The Buddha's words are sincere. I fear that if laypeople do not believe, they will fall into hell;
Even if those who believe the Buddha's words come to serve me again and make offerings to me, I do not like to trouble people, so I asked about it.
The bhiká¹£u took his leave and left.
The Aá¹…gulimÄla of Heti said:
I think you haven't eaten yet this morning, so stay and have a meal.
He then went to wash his hands and served the food.
After the meal, the bhiká¹£u returned and said to the Buddha:
Just now I went to the house of the Aá¹…gulimÄla of Heti, and on the way he said:
'The Buddha praised me greatly in the assembly.'
The Aá¹…gulimÄla of Heti then asked me:
'When the Buddha praised me, were there any laypeople present?'
I said:
'There were no laypeople.'
Even if there were laypeople, what suspicion could there be?'
The Aá¹…gulimÄla of Heti said:
'The Buddha's praise of me is truly sincere and not false. If laypeople who do not believe the Buddha's words, they will fall into the hells;
Even if someone has faith in me, they will come to serve me again. I do not like to trouble others, so I ask this.
The Buddha said:
Excellent!
Excellent!
I do not always tell you to rebuke Anavatapta for having seven things, but now I add one more thing to make it eight things.
What are the eight things?
First, not seeking, not wanting others to know;
Second, faith, not wanting others to know;ğŸ”½Third, self-shame, not wanting others to know;
Fourth, self-embarrassment, not wanting others to know;
Fifth, diligence, not wanting others to know;
Sixth, self-observation, not wanting others to know;
Seventh, attaining meditation, not wanting others to know;
Eighth, wisdom, not wanting others to know.
The reason why he did not want people to know was because he did not want to trouble others, so he did not want people to know.
After the Buddha spoke the sÅ«tra, all the bhiká¹£us greatly rejoiced and rose to bow to the Buddha.
